channel.title: BBC News - Home
channel.description: The latest stories from the Home section of the BBC News web site.
channel.copyright: Copyright: (C) British Broadcasting Corporation, see http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/help/rss/4498287.stm for terms and conditions of reuse.

item.title: Italy reopens Kercher murder case
item.description: Amanda Knox and Raffaele Sollecito have their acquittals for killing Briton Meredith Kercher in Italy overturned and face a re-run of their appeal.

item.title: No more covering up errors, NHS told
item.description: The NHS will have a legal duty to be honest about mistakes as part of an overhaul of the system in the wake of the Stafford Hospital scandal.

item.title: MPs warn over benefit cut risks
item.description: The government will need to react quickly if a benefit cut for social housing tenants leads to rises in rent arrears and homelessness, MPs say.

item.title: Cyprus to bring in capital controls
item.description: Cyprus's finance ministers are planning weekly cash withdrawal limits and other capital controls, as big depositors face 40% cuts in their funds.

item.title: Search and rescue role privatised
item.description: Private company the Bristow Group is to take over the UK's helicopter search and rescue operations, including those of the RAF and Royal Navy.

item.title: Snow prompts rise in Easter flights
item.description: There has been a surge in the number of Britons escaping abroad for Easter following the freezing and snowy weather, tourism operators say.

item.title: Ex-choirmaster jailed for abuse
item.description: A former choirmaster at Chetham's School of Music in Manchester is jailed for indecently assaulting a former pupil.

item.title: Savile police inquiry 'gone too far'
item.description: A former BBC producer who will not face charges over claims of indecent assault says the police's Operation Yewtree inquiry "has gone too far".

item.title: Young drivers 'could face curfew'
item.description: Motorists under the age of 24 could face a curfew in an effort to prevent accidents and reduce "sky-high" insurance premiums, ministers say.

item.title: Boris Berezovsky 'died by hanging'
item.description: A post-mortem examination has found Russian tycoon Boris Berezovsky's death to be "consistent with hanging", police say.

item.title: Thousands of jobless use food banks
item.description: Thousands of welfare claimants are being referred to food banks by Job Centre staff over concerns they have not got enough money to eat, the BBC learns.

item.title: Planting trees to beat ash dieback
item.description: The government is to plant 250,00 ash trees in an attempt to find strains that are resistant to the chalara fungus - the key to winning the long-term battle against ash dieback.

item.title: TV actor cleared of raping teenager
item.description: A young television actor is cleared by a jury at London's Blackfriars Crown Court of raping a 14-year-old boy.

item.title: Curious Incident leads Olivier race
item.description: The stage version of Mark Haddon's best-selling novel The Curious Incident Of The Dog In The Night-Time leads the pack for this year's Olivier Awards with eight nominations.

item.title: Secret crypts found under cathedral
item.description: Restoration workers discover nine secret crypts hidden under the ruins of Coventry's bombed cathedral.

item.title: Bids invited to run East Coast rail
item.description: The government invites private companies to bid for the East Coast rail franchise and also announces Virgin will run the West Coast Main Line until 2017.

item.title: B&Q owner profits hit by wet weather
item.description: The owner of B&Q, Kingfisher, reports a fall in profits after what it describes as "a tough year" of weak consumer confidence and wet weather.

item.title: 500 terror suspects 'deradicalised'
item.description: More than 500 individuals have been put through a counter-terrorism deradicalisation programme, the Home Office has revealed.

item.title: UK 'to compete' in nuclear market
item.description: The government promises funding to help UK businesses "compete" more effectively in the global nuclear energy market.

item.title: TV 'does not make children unruly'
item.description: Spending hours watching TV or playing computer games each day does not breed badly behaved children, say experts.

item.title: Social isolation 'ups death risk'
item.description: Social isolation is linked with a higher risk of death in older people, research suggests.

item.title: Pupils 'should learn risks of porn'
item.description: Pupils need to be protected from the dangers of pornography, the annual conference of the ATL teachers' union is told.

item.title: 'Unfair' university admissions claim
item.description: Ethnic minority students are less likely to get places at top universities than white pupils with the same A-level grades, according to research from Durham University.

item.title: Campaigners warn on Google Glass use
item.description: Google Glass and other augmented reality gadgets risk creating a world in which privacy is impossible, warn campaigners.

item.title: Prison for shining laser at aircraft
item.description: A 19-year-old California man is sentenced to two and a half years in prison for shining a laser pointer at two aircraft.

item.title: James Cameron's sub given to science
item.description: The submersible that took Hollywood director James Cameron to the deepest place in the ocean is being donated to science.

item.title: Butterflies 'hurt by cold, wet 2012'
item.description: Butterflies suffered in last year's wet and cold weather, having their worst year since 1976, a charity's study suggests.

item.title: Pompeii exhibition is a critical hit
item.description: The British Museum's latest exhibition of hidden treasures receives five-star reviews from critics.

item.title: Motown hits producer Richards dies
item.description: Motown songwriter-producer Deke Richards, who was behind songs including the Jackson 5's first three US number one hits, dies aged 68.

item.title: Has Street View changed the way we act?
item.description: While many people use Google Street View to look at the places they already know, has it also changed the way they relate to the wider world?

item.title: The people who think they tune in to dead voices
item.description: Jolyon Jenkins investigates the bizarre world of EVP, where people claim to listen to the dead on their radio equipment.

item.title: Prior earns England thrilling draw
item.description: Matt Prior hits an unbeaten 110 as England's last-wicket pair secure a draw in a thrilling final Test against New Zealand.

item.title: Reading appoint Adkins as manager
item.description: Premier League strugglers Reading appoint former Southampton boss Nigel Adkins as their new manager.

item.title: London Welsh appeal unsuccessful
item.description: London Welsh's appeal against a five-point deduction for fielding an ineligible player is turned down by an RFU disciplinary panel.

item.title: Noble in contention for Salford job
item.description: Brian Noble confirms he is in the running to replace Phil Veivers as head coach of Salford City Reds.

item.title: Does size matter in sport?
item.description: Population and economy size have long been an unreliable basis for predicting sporting success, says BBC sports editor David Bond

item.title: Two killed in Thailand road accident
item.description: Two men from Greater Manchester have been killed in a road accident while on holiday in Thailand, the government says.

item.title: Girl, three, struck by van dies
item.description: A three-year-old girl dies after being hit by a van in Croydon, south London.

item.title: More than 3,000 still without power
item.description: Thousands of people in the west of Scotland spend a fourth night without electricity after Friday's winter storm brought down power lines.

item.title: Consent for Trump row wind farm
item.description: Consent for a wind farm off Aberdeen which is opposed by Donald Trump is granted by the Scottish government, angering the US businessman.

item.title: RAF to help snowbound NI animals
item.description: A Ministry of Defence helicopter will be used to get food to snowbound animals in Northern Ireland as farmers fear for their livestock and livelihoods.

item.title: Energy prices 'among highest in EU'
item.description: Energy costs for manufacturers in Northern Ireland are among the highest in Europe, according to a report.

item.title: 'Alarming rate' of measles epidemic
item.description: The number of measles cases in the Swansea area more than doubles in the last three weeks, with health officials warning the epidemic is spreading across Wales "at an alarming rate".

item.title: Helicopter rescue at two new bases
item.description: Helicopter search and rescue will move to Caernarfon from Anglesey and a new base will be set up at St Athan as an American firm wins a £1.6bn deal to run the UK service.

item.title: DR Congo's Ntaganda appears at ICC
item.description: Congolese war crimes suspect Bosco Ntaganda appears in court at the Hague for the first time after surrendering to the International Criminal Court.

item.title: Nigeria militant jailed for 24 years
item.description: South African court jails Nigerian oil militant Henry Okah to 24 years in jail over 2010 twin bombings in Abuja.

item.title: N Korea 'combat posture to hit US'
item.description: North Korea orders artillery and rocket units into "combat posture" to prepare to target US bases, as South Korea marks a deadly warship sinking.

item.title: Vietnam-China spat over sea clash
item.description: China defends the action of one of its patrol boats which is accused of opening fire on a Vietnamese fishing boat last week in the South China Sea.

item.title: EU backs Croatia to join in July
item.description: The European Commission gives Croatia the green light to join the EU on 1 July as the 28th member state.

item.title: EU suspends most Zimbabwe sanctions
item.description: The European Union suspends sanctions against 81 officials and eight firms in Zimbabwe following what it called a "successful" constitutional referendum.

item.title: Chile miner trapped 300m underground
item.description: A collapse in a mine in northern Chile in the early hours of Monday leaves a miner trapped 300m underground.

item.title: Brazil supermarkets ban Amazon meat
item.description: Almost 3,000 supermarkets in Brazil are pledging to avoid selling meat from cattle raised in the Amazon rainforest to curb illegal deforestation.

item.title: Opposition takes Syria summit seat
item.description: Syria's opposition National Coalition takes the official seat of the country at the start of a two-day Arab League summit in Qatar.

item.title: UAE trial of 94 slammed as 'unfair'
item.description: A coalition of international human rights organisations releases a report calling the trial of 94 activists in the United Arab Emirates "flagrantly unfair".

item.title: US court to review gay marriage ban
item.description: The US Supreme Court is to hear two landmark cases this week on gay marriage that could reshape the legal definition of marriage in America.

item.title: Native Canadians finish arduous trek
item.description: Seven young Native Canadian men finish a 1,600km (1,000-mile) trek to Ottawa, the Canadian capital, in protest against living conditions on reserves.

item.title: Day in pictures: 26 March 2013
item.description: Twenty-four hours of news photos: 26 March

item.title: In pictures: Shifting Perspectives
item.description: Representation of people with Down’s syndrome

item.title: Day in pictures: 25 March 2013
item.description: Twenty-four hours of news photos: 25 March

item.title: In Pictures: Rowena Cade's theatre
item.description: The Minack Theatre prepares for its new season

item.title: In pictures: Earth Hour around the world
item.description: Images from around the world of Earth Hour

item.title: Week in pictures: 16-22 March 2013
item.description: A selection of the best photos from the news

item.title: Day in pictures: 22 March 2013
item.description: Twenty-four hours of news photos: 22 March

item.title: In pictures: Lives in limbo on India-Bangladesh border
item.description: Alakananda Nag explores the India-Bangladesh border

item.title: VIDEO: House of Commons
item.description: Jeremy Hunt is making a statement on the Mid Staffordshire NHS Trust inquiry.

item.title: VIDEO: N Korea in 'combat posture No 1'
item.description: North Korea says it has ordered artillery and rocket units into "combat posture" to prepare to target US bases in Hawaii, Guam and the US mainland.

item.title: VIDEO: 'My husband drank from a vase'
item.description: A woman who lost three family members at Stafford Hospital describes how her husband, Tom, had to resort to drinking from a vase when he was a patient.

item.title: VIDEO: Is the 'teen rebel' a dying breed?
item.description: The BBC's Home Editor, Mark Easton, was a teenager during the punk rock era and he reflects on whether today's youth has lost some of the rebelliousness of that time.

item.title: AUDIO: Savile suspect: 'Inquiry has gone too far'
item.description: A former BBC producer released without charge yesterday after being arrested by detectives investigating the Savile abuse scandal says the police operation has "gone too far".

item.title: VIDEO: Reinventing the New York payphone
item.description: With mobile phones part of everyday life, the city of New York holds a competition to reinvent the payphone and ensure it will remain relevant in the future.

item.title: VIDEO: British butterflies hit by 2012 weather
item.description: Several species of British butterflies face extinction in some areas because of last year's extremely wet weather.

item.title: VIDEO: Snow turns Ukraine street into piste
item.description: A makeshift ski slope has appeared in Ukraine's capital Kiev after record snowfall.

item.title: VIDEO: Does Iraq have a future?
item.description: The BBC's World Affairs Editor John Simpson has covered events in Iraq for 28 years and looks at what sort of future the country faces.

item.title: Why are the French drinking less wine?
item.description: Why the French are holding back on the wine

item.title: Should Britain let go of London?
item.description: Is London's success ruining the rest of the UK's chances?

item.title: Living life to the extreme
item.description: Learning from the creatures of the world's most hostile environments

item.title: Life on the front line of the NHS
item.description: What is life like on the front line of the NHS?

item.title: Boyle plays down 'treasure' tag
item.description: Danny Boyle plays down post-Olympics 'hero' tag

item.title: Playing games with culture
item.description: Game maker Ken Levine on what makes video games matter

item.title: Boris Johnson and the future PM question
item.description: Boris Johnson and the future PM question

item.title: Alzheimer's: A different view
item.description: Taking a different view of Alzheimer's disease

item.title: Offshore staff 'get tea and cake'
item.description: Why the southern North Sea is booming

item.title: UK banks 'still short of capital'
item.description: UK banks 'still short of capital'
